874.text: THAT'S A MYTH, AND I'M GOING TO TELL YOU WHY.

879.text:
I'M ASSOCIATE PROFESSOR OF EMERGENCY MEDICINE
AT THE UNIVERSITY OF ROCHESTER SCHOOL OF MEDICINE

885.text:
CURRENTLY THE WAY A CONCUSSION IS DEFINED
IS A BLOW TO THE HEAD OR RAPID DECELERATION

891.text:
OF THE HEAD THAT RESULTS IN A BRIEF PERIOD
OF BEING KNOCKED OUT; OR NOT REMEMBERING,

897.text: WHICH WE CALL AMNESIA; OR BEING CONFUSED.

900.text:
SO IT'S ONE OF THOSE THREE THINGS THAT WILL
GET YOU A DIAGNOSIS OF A CONCUSSION.

904.text: THERE'S NO LAB TEST OR X-RAY.

907.text: IT'S BASED SOLELY ON THOSE SYMPTOMS.

910.text:
THERE'S PROBLEMS WITH THAT, OBVIOUSLY, BECAUSE
IF PEOPLE CAN'T REMEMBER WHAT HAPPENED, THAT

915.text:
MAKES IT HARD FOR DOCTORS TO DIAGNOSE WHETHER
YOU'VE HAD A CONCUSSION OR NOT.

920.text: BUT UNFORTUNATELY IN 2013 THAT'S WHAT WE HAVE.

925.text:
DUSTIN, FROM RALEIGH, NORTH CAROLINA, ASKS,
"IF A CAT SCAN DOESN'T RULE OUT A CONCUSSION,

931.text:
IN A SMALL PERCENTAGE OF PEOPLE THAT HAVE
CONCUSSION, THERE CAN BE BLEEDING IN THE BRAIN.

935.text:
IT'S NOT POSSIBLE TO TELL WHO'S GOT BLEEDING
IN THE BRAIN JUST BY THOSE SYMPTOMS OF LOSS

943.text:
THAT'S WHY IT'S IMPORTANT TO GET A CAT SCAN,
AND IT'S HARD TO KNOW WHO NEEDS A CAT SCAN

947.text:
WITHOUT ACTUALLY GOING TO A DOCTOR IN AN EMERGENCY
ROOM OR TALKING TO YOUR DOCTOR ON THE PHONE

954.text:
EVERY CONCUSSION HAS THE POTENTIAL FOR THIS
LIFE-THREATENING BLEEDING IN THE BRAIN THAT

959.text:
CAN ONLY BE DETECTED WITH A CT SCAN OR MRI.
AND THAT'S MEDICINE.

TO HAPPEN IN SOCCER OR MANY OF THE OTHER SPORTS
THAT OCCUR.

1107.text:
I THINK THE IMPORTANT THING IS TO RECOGNIZE
THAT -- TO DO EARLY AND QUICK EVALUATION.

1113.text:
IF A PLAYER TAKES A HIT, IF THEY FALL, TO

1120.text:

THE ATHLETE IS ALMOST ALWAYS GOING TO SAY

1128.text: THAT CAN'T BE THE SINGLE DETERMINING FACTOR.

1130.text: NOW, YOU STILL HAVE HEADACHES, DON'T YOU?

1135.text:
I MEAN, I HAVE MILD HEADACHES MAYBE ONCE OR

1141.text: A MONTH, ONCE EVERY TWO MONTHS OR SO.

1148.text:

1153.text: I'VE TRIED CHANGING MY DIET, CHANGING MY EXERCISE.

1163.text:
UM, SOME OF THEM HAD A LITTLE BIT OF HELP
KIND OF LIKE RELIEVING SYMPTOMS, BUT I GUESS

1167.text:
NO LONG-TERM SUCCESS, NOTHING THAT ELIMINATED

1171.text:

1175.text:
IS THIS MORE LIKE MIGRAINE, OR DO YOU THINK
WE CAN BLAME THIS, CAN YOU BLAME THIS ON A

1182.text:
WELL, I WOULD CALL IT POST-TRAUMATIC MIGRAINE,
WHICH IS A VARIANT.

1184.text: IT'S A VARIANT OF POST-CONCUSSION SYNDROME?

1190.text:
OKAY, SO IT IS RELATED, YOU THINK, TO THE

1193.text:
IT SOUNDS LIKE IT IN TERMS OF WHEN IT BEGAN,
AND IT HASN'T STOPPED COMPLETELY SINCE THAT

1197.text: DO THESE THINGS EVER JUST GO AWAY BY THEMSELVES?

I THINK THE BRAIN HEALS, AND WHATEVER ONGOING

1205.text:

1213.text:
PART OF THE ISSUE -- WE'VE GOT TO LET HER

1216.text:
SHE WENT THROUGH COLLEGE AND WAS STUDYING
ALL THE TIME AND NOW SHE'S IN GRADUATE SCHOOL,

1220.text:
AND SHE'S CONTINUING TO UTILIZE HER BRAIN
--

1223.text:
BUT WAIT, LET ME SEE IF I UNDERSTAND WHAT

1227.text: WILL HURT THE HEALING PROCESS FROM A CONCUSSION?

1232.text:
THAT'S LIKE IF YOU BREAK YOUR LEG AND YOU
KEEP RUNNING ON IT.

1235.text: BUT SHE'S NOT HITTING IT INTO A WALL.

1238.text:
SHE DOESN'T HAVE TO HIT IT, IT'S THE COGNITIVE
FUNCTION.

1240.text: IS THAT -- DO YOU AGREE WITH THAT?

1244.text:
THAT'S A DIFFICULT TRADE-OFF IN LIFE, AND
THAT'S A DIFFICULT TRADE-OFF FOR STUDENT ATHLETES.

1247.text:
IT'S DIFFICULT FOR PEOPLE WHO MAKE A PROFESSION
PLAYING ATHLETICS.

1253.text:
FOR ANY WALK OF LIFE, IT'S HARD TO PUT YOUR
LIFE ON HOLD.

SO MANAGING THAT STIMULATION, FOR INSTANCE
FOR KIDS, WE DON'T WANT THEM TO PLAY VIDEO

1261.text: GAMES AND HAVE ALL THAT STIMULATION.

1263.text:
BUT AFTER A CERTAIN PERIOD OF TIME, IF YOU
KEEP THEM OUT OF SCHOOL TOO LONG, IT'S DIMINISHING

1276.text: WHERE DO YOU THINK YOU ARE ON THAT?

ARE YOU READY NOT TO GO TO SCHOOL FOR A WHILE
AND SIT IN A DARK ROOM AND LET YOUR BRAIN

1281.text:
I MEAN, AND THAT'S ONE OF THE REASONS I STOPPED
? I DECIDED TO STOP PLAYING BECAUSE I WANTED

1283.text: TO MAKE SURE THAT I COULD FINISH MY DEGREE.

BUT SHE'S ACTUALLY SAYING FINISHING YOUR STUDIES
MIGHT AT LEAST IN PART BE CONTRIBUTING TO

1293.text:
WELL, I STARE AT A COMPUTER SCREEN ALL DAY
LONG EVERY DAY FOR MY WORK, SO I WOULD IMAGINE

1299.text:
WHICH BRINGS US TO THE REASON THAT YOU'RE
REALLY HERE, AMONG MANY, BUT YOU'RE HERE FOR

1305.text: WE HAVE GREAT EXPERTS FOR YOU.

1307.text:
THIS IS YOUR OPPORTUNITY TO ASK YOUR QUESTIONS
FOR A SECOND OPINION.

1312.text:
YEAH, I'VE STARTED TRACKING MY HEADACHES,
SO I WRITE DOWN EVERY TIME I GET THEM AND

1316.text:
AND IS THIS JUST SOMETHING I SHOULD LIVE WITH
AND DEAL WITH?

1320.text:
OR WHAT WOULD YOU SUGGEST AS FAR AS SEEKING
TREATMENT OR SEEING SOMEBODY?

1326.text:
I THINK YOU NEED TO SEE A HEADACHE SPECIALIST
AND NOT JUST A NEUROLOGIST OR A NEUROSURGEON,

1330.text:
BUT SOMEONE WHO REALLY SPECIALIZES IN HEADACHES
AND PARTICULARLY MIGRAINE OR POST-TRAUMATIC

1335.text:
MIGRAINE, BECAUSE I THINK THERE ARE SOME TREATMENTS
OUT THERE THAT IT DOESN'T SOUND LIKE YOU MAY

1341.text:
THERE IS SOME PREVENTATIVE THERAPY THAT MAY
BE BENEFICIAL TO YOU.

1345.text:
SOUNDS LIKE SHE'S TRIED A LOT, AND I AGREE,
YOU'VE MADE A GREAT EFFORT AT TRYING TO OVERCOME

1350.text:
THIS, AND I WOULD AGREE THAT A HEADACHE SPECIALIST,
ORDINARILY A NEUROLOGIST OR HEADACHE CLINIC,

1356.text:
HAS THE MOST EXPERTISE AND CAN MAKE THE MOST
PROGRESS.

1359.text:
A LOT OF IT IS PART OF LIFESTYLE -- THAT INCLUDES
DIET, EXERCISE, SLEEP PATTERNS, HOW YOU MANAGE

1364.text: YOUR WORK AND YOUR SCHOOL AND STUDY RESPONSIBILITIES.

1367.text:
BUT PROBABLY THAT'S THE STAGE YOU'RE AT NOW,
THAT YOU NEED THAT EXPERTISE.

1377.text:
I JUST WONDER, IS THIS, AM I, SHOULD I EXPECT
TO DEAL WITH HEADACHES FOREVER?

1382.text: OR IS IT SOMETHING THAT COULD BE --

1386.text:
I WOULD SAY, NO, I DON'T THINK YOU SHOULD
EXPECT TO LIVE WITH PAIN FOR THE REST OF YOUR

1391.text:
I THINK THAT'S SOMETHING THAT CAN BE AGGRESSIVELY
--

1394.text: I'LL GIVE YOU THE LAST WORD.

1397.text: I AGREE, I THINK THERE'S OPTIMISM.

1398.text:
YOU'RE NO LONGER GETTING THAT STIMULUS OF
HITTING YOUR HEAD ALL OF THE TIME, BUT IT'S

1400.text:
A COMMITMENT TO GETTING BETTER, WHETHER IT'S
MEDICATION OR ALL THE LIFESTYLE THINGS.

1406.text:
I WANT TO THANK BOTH OF YOU FOR BEING HERE,
AND, MONICA, THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR SHARING

1410.text:
YOUR STORY, AND I HOPE WE GAVE YOU A SECOND
OPINION THAT WAS AT LEAST PARTIALLY HELPFUL.

1414.text:
AND NOW FOR THE LAST WORD ON CONCUSSIONS,
HERE IS THIS WEEK'S "SECOND OPINION 5."

1422.text:
ELIZABETH MURRAY, AND I'M HERE TO TELL YOU
THE FIVE SIGNS OF WHEN TO GO TO THE EMERGENCY

1428.text:
THE FIRST SIGN IS LARGE BRUISING AT THE SITE
OF INJURY.

1430.text:
BUMPS AND BRUISES ARE COMMON, BUT A LARGE
AMOUNT OF SWELLING OR BRUISING, OFTEN CALLED

1434.text:
A GOOSE EGG, ON THE SIDES OR THE BACK OF THE
SKULL CAN BE CONCERNING.

1438.text:
HOW THE INJURY HAPPENED IS ALSO A FACTOR TO
TAKE INTO CONSIDERATION.

1441.text:
A FALL FROM STANDING IS ALMOST NEVER GOING
TO HURT YOU, BUT A FALL ON A ROCK IS A DIFFERENT

1447.text:
INJURIES FROM HARD OR SHARP OBJECTS WILL OFTEN
CAUSE THAT BRUISING AND SWELLING WE JUST DISCUSSED.

1452.text: THE THIRD SIGN IS UNCONTROLLED VOMITING.

1454.text:
NO ONE WANTS TO FEEL NAUSEOUS OR THROW UP,
BUT ONE OF TWO EPISODES OF VOMITING CAN BE

1459.text:
IT'S THE PERSON WITH UNCONTROLLED VOMITING
OR PROFOUND NAUSEA THAT WARRANTS FURTHER EVALUATION.

1463.text:
IF YOU'RE EXPERIENCING ALTERED MENTAL STATE
OR AMNESIA, THIS IS ANOTHER SIGN TO GET YOU

1468.text: OR YOUR LOVED ONE TO THE EMERGENCY ROOM.

1470.text:
CONFUSION IS COMMON FOR A FEW MINUTES AFTER
A HEAD INJURY, BUT IF A PERSON IS REPEATING

1474.text:
THE SAME QUESTION OVER AND OVER AGAIN OR REALLY
SEEMS OUT OF IT, HAVE THEM EVALUATED.

1478.text:
AND THE LAST SIGN IS LOSS OF CONSCIOUSNESS
OR SEIZURES, AND THIS IS A TRUE MEDICAL EMERGENCY.

1484.text:
IF A PERSON IS KNOCKED OUT FOR MORE THAN FIVE
SECONDS OR APPEARS TO BE HAVING SEIZURES,

1487.text:
THEN YOU NEED TO STAY WITH THEM AND HAVE SOMEONE
CALL 911.

1491.text:
REMEMBER, YOU KNOW YOUR COMFORT LEVEL BEST,
AND YOU KNOW YOUR CHILD BEST.

1494.text:
IF SOMETHING SEEMS WRONG TO YOU OR YOU ARE
UNCOMFORTABLE, REACH OUT TO YOUR PEDIATRICIAN

1498.text: OR COME SEE US IN THE EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT.

1511.text: THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR WATCHING "SECOND OPINION."

1513.text:
WE HOPE THAT YOU CONTINUE THIS CONVERSATION
ON OUR WEBSITE, WHERE YOU CAN COMMENT ON THE

1517.text:
SHOW, SEND US YOUR SHOW IDEAS, OR EVEN SHARE
YOUR HEALTH STORY WITH US, AND MAYBE WE'LL

1522.text: EVEN INVITE YOU TO BE ON THE SHOW WITH US.

1531.text:
PETER SALGO, AND I'LL SEE YOU NEXT TIME FOR
ANOTHER "SECOND OPINION."
